complaint_summary: The Department alleged discrepancies in the declaration of cash-in-hand and questioned the validity of a Waqf created by the deceased.
investigation_summary: The Assessing Officer proposed an estimated cash-in-hand of Rs. 5,000 based on social and financial status of the deceased, and rejected the Waqf claim due to non-execution of Trust Deed during the deceased's lifetime.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal ruled that the Department's estimation of cash-in-hand was arbitrary and unsupported by evidence. It accepted the declared amount of Rs. 730. The Tribunal also upheld the validity of the Waqf created by the deceased through a written will dated 7-1-1979, declaring the insurance amount and properties as Waqf property effective from the date of the will.
Decision_or_verdict: The Tribunal modified the impugned order, accepting the declared cash-in-hand and recognizing the Waqf as valid.
legal_arguments: Presumption of cash-in-hand based on social and financial status is erroneous.
Waqf creation requires only a declaration of endowment by the owner.
Non-execution of Trust Deed does not invalidate a legally created Waqf.

witness_statement.Witnesses to the will: Confirmed the deceased's declaration of Waqf through a written will dated 7-1-1979.

key_issues: Validity of Waqf created through a will

maxims.Waqf creation: A Waqf is irrevocable once declared by the owner.

legal_terms.Waqf: Permanent dedication of property for religious, pious, or charitable purposes under Islamic law.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the validity of a Waqf created by the deceased and the arbitrary estimation of cash-in-hand by the Department. The Tribunal ruled in favor of the appellant, recognizing the Waqf and rejecting the Department's estimation.
